file.content:
[package]
name = "ai_translate"
version = "0.1.0"
description = "A Tauri App"
authors = ["you"]
edition = "2021"

# See more keys and their definitions at https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/manifest.html

[lib]
# The `_lib` suffix may seem redundant but it is necessary
# to make the lib name unique and wouldn't conflict with the bin name.
# This seems to be only an issue on Windows, see https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/issues/8519
name = "ai_translate_lib"
crate-type = ["staticlib", "cdylib", "rlib"]

[build-dependencies]
tauri-build = { version = "2", features = [] }

[dependencies]
tauri = { version = "2", features = ["tray-icon"] }
tauri-plugin-opener = "2"
tauri-plugin-single-instance = "2"
serde = { version = "1", features = ["derive"] }
serde_json = "1"
tauri-plugin-global-shortcut = "2.3.1"
tauri-plugin-clipboard-manager = "2.3.2"
reqwest = { version = "0.13.1", features = ["json"] }
enigo = "0.6.1"
arboard = "3.6.1"
log = "0.4.29"
env_logger = "0.11.8"
rdev = "0.5.3"
tauri-plugin-store = "2"
once_cell = "1.19"
tokio = { version = "1", features = ["sync"] }

[target.'cfg(windows)'.dependencies]
window-vibrancy = "0.5"

toolUseResult.originalFile:
[package]
name = "simple_translate"
version = "0.1.0"
description = "Simple Translate - Windows Desktop Translation Tool"
authors = ["you"]
edition = "2021"

# See more keys and their definitions at https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/manifest.html

[lib]
# The `_lib` suffix may seem redundant but it is necessary
# to make the lib name unique and wouldn't conflict with the bin name.
# This seems to be only an issue on Windows, see https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/issues/8519
name = "ai_translate_lib"
crate-type = ["staticlib", "cdylib", "rlib"]

[build-dependencies]
tauri-build = { version = "2", features = [] }

[dependencies]
tauri = { version = "2", features = ["tray-icon"] }
tauri-plugin-opener = "2"
tauri-plugin-single-instance = "2"
serde = { version = "1", features = ["derive"] }
serde_json = "1"
tauri-plugin-global-shortcut = "2.3.1"
tauri-plugin-clipboard-manager = "2.3.2"
reqwest = { version = "0.13.1", features = ["json"] }
enigo = "0.6.1"
arboard = "3.6.1"
log = "0.4.29"
env_logger = "0.11.8"
rdev = "0.5.3"
tauri-plugin-store = "2"
once_cell = "1.19"
tokio = { version = "1", features = ["sync"] }

[target.'cfg(windows)'.dependencies]
window-vibrancy = "0.5"

lines: # The `_lib` suffix may seem redundant but it is necessary
# to make the lib name unique and wouldn't conflict with the bin name.
# This seems to be only an issue on Windows, see https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/issues/8519

# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Project Overview

**ai_translate** is a Windows desktop translation tool built with Tauri 2.0, React, and Rust. It provides instant translation via a global hotkey (Ctrl+Q) that displays results in a floating popup window.

## Development Commands

toolUseResult.originalFile:
# CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

## Project Overview

**ai_translate** is a Windows desktop translation tool built with Tauri 2.0, React, and Rust. It provides instant translation via a global hotkey (Ctrl+Q) that displays results in a floating popup window.

## Development Commands

```bash
# Frontend development
npm run dev          # Start Vite dev server on port 1420
npm run build        # TypeScript type check + build frontend
npm run preview      # Preview built app

# Full Tauri application
npm run tauri dev    # Run full app in development mode (builds Rust + frontend)
npm run tauri build  # Build application packages for distribution

# Rust backend (run from src-tauri/)
cargo build          # Build Rust backend
cargo check          # Check Rust code without building
cargo add <crate>    # Add Rust dependency
```

## Architecture

The application follows a clear separation of concerns:

### Frontend-Backend Communication

The architecture uses **Tauri events** for one-way communication (Rust â†’ React) and **Tauri commands** for request-response (React â†’ Rust):

```
User Action (Ctrl+Q)
    â†“
Rust: trigger_translate() [lib.rs]
    â†“
Rust: get_selected_text() â†’ get_mouse_position()
    â†“
Rust: emit "translate-text" event
    â†“
React: App.tsx listens for event â†’ shows popup
    â†“
React: invoke "translate" command
    â†“
Rust: translate() â†’ HTTP request to DeepLX API
    â†“
React: displays result
```

### Key Components

**Rust Backend (`src-tauri/src/lib.rs`)**:
- `run()` - Initializes Tauri app with global shortcuts and system tray
- `trigger_translate()` - Global shortcut handler (Ctrl+Q) with 300ms debounce
- `get_selected_text()` - Clipboard-based text extraction using `enigo` for Ctrl+C simulation and `arboard` for clipboard reading
- `get_mouse_position()` - Tracks cursor position for popup placement
- `translate()` - HTTP POST to DeepLX API (EN â†’ ZH), max 1000 chars, 10s timeout

**React Frontend (`src/App.tsx`)**:
- Listens for "translate-text" events from Rust
- Manages popup window positioning with boundary detection
- Handles copy-to-clipboard via `@tauri-apps/plugin-clipboard-manager`
- Auto-hides after 1.5s of mouse leave

### Translation API

- Endpoint: `https://api.deeplx.org/pIcaK4I42id_1BwHBrx2z2trJ5EaE2aG0qwVD8gmYuo/translate`
- Request format: `{ "text": "...", "source_lang": "EN", "target_lang": "ZH" }`
- Response: `TranslateResult { success: bool, text: string, error: string }`

### Window Configuration

The window is defined in `tauri.conf.json`:
- Size: 320x200 (auto-resizes based on content)
- Frameless, transparent, always-on-top
- Starts hidden (`visible: false`)
- Shows only when translation is triggered

## Important Notes

- The clipboard text extraction saves the original clipboard content, simulates Ctrl+C, reads the new content, then restores the original clipboard.
- Text is trimmed to a maximum of 1000 characters before translation.
- The global shortcut has a 300ms debounce to prevent rapid-fire triggers.
- The popup window positions near the mouse cursor with boundary detection to keep it on-screen.

lines: -**ai_translate** is a Windows desktop translation tool built with Tauri 2.0, React, and Rust. It provides instant translation via a global hotkey (Ctrl+Q) that displays results in a floating popup window.

        &app,
        "settings",
        WebviewUrl::App("settings.html".into())

    .center()
    .build()
    .map_err(|e| format!("Failed to create settings window: {}", e))?;

    Ok(())
}

content.text:
I'll now provide you with a comprehensive analysis of the settings system implementation in the ai_translate project.

## Settings System Implementation Analysis

### 1. **AppSettings Structure** (Rust Backend)

**Location:** `E:\AI\Code\ai_translate\src-tauri\src\lib.rs` (lines 42-63)

```rust
#[derive(Serialize, Deserialize, Clone, Debug)]
struct AppSettings {
    api_key: String,
    auto_close_timeout: u64,
    source_lang: String,
    target_lang: String,
    first_run: bool,
    shortcut: String,
}

impl Default for AppSettings {
    fn default() -> Self {
        Self {
            api_key: String::new(),
            auto_close_timeout: 1500,
            source_lang: "EN".to_string(),
            target_lang: "ZH".to_string(),
            first_run: true,
            shortcut: "Ctrl+Q".to_string(),
        }
    }
}
```

**Current Fields:**
- `api_key`: DeepLX API authentication key (required)
- `auto_close_timeout`: Milliseconds before popup auto-closes (default: 1500ms)
- `source_lang`: Source language code (default: "EN")
- `target_lang`: Target language code (default: "ZH")
- `first_run`: Flag to show settings on first launch (default: true)
- `shortcut`: Global hotkey combination (default: "Ctrl+Q")

**Serialization:** Uses `serde` with JSON format via `tauri_plugin_store`

---

### 2. **Settings Cache System**

**Location:** `E:\AI\Code\ai_translate\src-tauri\src\lib.rs` (lines 65-69)

```rust
static SETTINGS_CACHE: Lazy<Arc<RwLock<AppSettings>>> =
    Lazy::new(|| Arc::new(RwLock::new(AppSettings::default())));

static CURRENT_SHORTCUT: Lazy<Arc<RwLock<Option<Shortcut>>>> =
    Lazy::new(|| Arc::new(RwLock::new(None)));
```

- Settings are cached in memory using `Arc<RwLock<>>` for thread-safe access
- Cache is loaded on app startup and updated whenever settings are saved
- Allows fast access without repeated file I/O

---

### 3. **Tauri Commands for Settings Management**

#### **get_settings** (lines 287-328)
```rust
#[tauri::command]
async fn get_settings(app: AppHandle) -> Result<AppSettings, String>
```
- Reads from persistent store (`settings.json`)
- Updates in-memory cache
- Returns complete `AppSettings` struct

#### **save_settings** (lines 331-372)
```rust
#[tauri::command]
async fn save_settings(
    app: AppHandle,
    api_key: String,
    auto_close_timeout: u64,
    source_lang: String,
    target_lang: String,
    shortcut: String,
) -> Result<(), String>
```
- Persists settings to store
- Updates cache
- Triggers shortcut re-registration
- Emits `settings-updated` event to notify other windows

#### **validate_api_key** (lines 375-411)
- Tests API key with a test translation request
- Returns `true` if valid, error message if invalid

#### **validate_shortcut** (lines 414-424)
- Checks if shortcut is available (not already registered)
- Returns `true` if valid

#### **update_shortcut** (lines 427-441)
- Unregisters old shortcut
- Registers new shortcut with global listener
- Updates `CURRENT_SHORTCUT` cache

#### **open_settings_window** (lines 444-469)
- Creates or shows settings window
- Window size: 650x660 pixels
- Loads `settings.html` entry point

---

### 4. **Plugin Initialization** (lines 498-505)

```rust
tauri::Builder::default()
    .plugin(tauri_plugin_single_instance::init(...))
    .plugin(tauri_plugin_opener::init())
    .plugin(tauri_plugin_global_shortcut::Builder::new().build())
    .plugin(tauri_plugin_clipboard_manager::init())
    .plugin(tauri_plugin_store::Builder::default().build())
```

**Initialized Plugins:**
- `single_instance`: Prevents multiple app instances
- `opener`: Opens URLs/files
- `global_shortcut`: Registers global hotkeys
- `clipboard_manager`: Clipboard operations
- `store`: Persistent JSON storage for settings

---

### 5. **Settings Page UI** (React Frontend)

**Location:** `E:\AI\Code\ai_translate\src\Settings.tsx`

**Current Settings Controls:**

1. **API Key Input** (lines 157-170)
   - Password input field
   - Placeholder: "sk-..."
   - Monospace font

2. **Language Direction** (lines 174-226)
   - Source language dropdown (14 languages)
   - Target language dropdown (14 languages)
   - Supported: EN, ZH, JA, KO, FR, DE, ES, RU, IT, PT, AR, NL, PL, TR

3. **Auto-close Timeout** (lines 228-247)
   - Dropdown with preset values: 1s, 1.5s (default), 2s, 3s

4. **Global Shortcut** (lines 249-276)
   - Read-only input field
   - Records key combination on focus
   - Reset button to restore "Ctrl+Q"
   - Validation: requires modifier key (Ctrl/Shift/Alt)

**State Management:**
```typescript
const [apiKey, setApiKey] = useState("");
const [timeout, setTimeoutValue] = useState(1500);
const [sourceLang, setSourceLang] = useState("EN");
const [targetLang, setTargetLang] = useState("ZH");
const [shortcut, setShortcut] = useState("Ctrl+Q");
const [isRecording, setIsRecording] = useState(false);
```

**Save Flow:**
1. Validate API key is not empty
2. Validate API key with backend
3. Validate shortcut is available
4. Call `save_settings` command
5. Show success/error toast

---

### 6. **Settings Lifecycle**

**Startup (lines 506-530):**
1. App initializes
2. `get_settings` loads from store
3. If `first_run=true` and `api_key` is empty â†’ show settings window
4. Register global shortcut from settings

**Runtime:**
1. User modifies settings in Settings window
2. Clicks "Save Changes"
3. Frontend validates and calls `save_settings`
4. Backend updates store and cache
5. Backend emits `settings-updated` event
6. Main window listens and updates `autoCloseTimeout` (lines 233-236 in App.tsx)

---

### 7. **Settings Persistence**

- **Storage Location:** `settings.json` (managed by `tauri_plugin_store`)
- **Format:** JSON key-value pairs
- **Typical Path:** `%APPDATA%\ai_translate\settings.json` (Windows)

---

### 8. **Adding New Settings - Pattern**

To add a new setting, follow this pattern:

**Rust (lib.rs):**
1. Add field to `AppSettings` struct
2. Add default value in `impl Default`
3. Update `get_settings` to read from store
4. Update `save_settings` to accept and persist the field
5. Update `save_settings` to update cache

**React (Settings.tsx):**
1. Add state variable
2. Load in `loadSettings()`
3. Add UI control
4. Pass to `save_settings` invoke call

---

### 9. **Key Design Patterns**

| Pattern | Implementation |
|---------|-----------------|
| **Caching** | In-memory `Arc<RwLock<>>` for fast access |
| **Persistence** | JSON store via `tauri_plugin_store` |
| **Validation** | Frontend + backend validation |
| **Events** | `settings-updated` event for cross-window sync |
| **Async** | All commands are async for non-blocking I/O |
| **Error Handling** | Result types with descriptive error messages |

---

This structure provides a clean, extensible settings system with proper separation between frontend UI, backend logic, and persistent storage. The caching mechanism ensures performance while the event system keeps the UI synchronized across windows.

- `single_instance`: Prevents multiple app instances
- `opener`: Opens URLs/files
- `global_shortcut`: Registers global hotkeys
- `clipboard_manager`: Clipboard operations
- `store`: Persistent JSON storage for settings

---

### 5. **Settings Page UI** (React Frontend)

**Location:** `E:\AI\Code\ai_translate\src\Settings.tsx`

**Current Settings Controls:**

1. **API Key Input** (lines 157-170)
   - Password input field
   - Placeholder: "sk-..."
   - Monospace font

2. **Language Direction** (lines 174-226)
   - Source language dropdown (14 languages)
   - Target language dropdown (14 languages)
   - Supported: EN, ZH, JA, KO, FR, DE, ES, RU, IT, PT, AR, NL, PL, TR

3. **Auto-close Timeout** (lines 228-247)
   - Dropdown with preset values: 1s, 1.5s (default), 2s, 3s

4. **Global Shortcut** (lines 249-276)
   - Read-only input field
   - Records key combination on focus
   - Reset button to restore "Ctrl+Q"
   - Validation: requires modifier key (Ctrl/Shift/Alt)

**State Management:**
```typescript
const [apiKey, setApiKey] = useState("");
const [timeout, setTimeoutValue] = useState(1500);
const [sourceLang, setSourceLang] = useState("EN");
const [targetLang, setTargetLang] = useState("ZH");
const [shortcut, setShortcut] = useState("Ctrl+Q");
const [isRecording, setIsRecording] = useState(false);
```

**Save Flow:**
1. Validate API key is not empty
2. Validate API key with backend
3. Validate shortcut is available
4. Call `save_settings` command
5. Show success/error toast

---

### 6. **Settings Lifecycle**

**Startup (lines 506-530):**
1. App initializes
2. `get_settings` loads from store
3. If `first_run=true` and `api_key` is empty â†’ show settings window
4. Register global shortcut from settings

**Runtime:**
1. User modifies settings in Settings window
2. Clicks "Save Changes"
3. Frontend validates and calls `save_settings`
4. Backend updates store and cache
5. Backend emits `settings-updated` event
6. Main window listens and updates `autoCloseTimeout` (lines 233-236 in App.tsx)

---

### 7. **Settings Persistence**

- **Storage Location:** `settings.json` (managed by `tauri_plugin_store`)
- **Format:** JSON key-value pairs
- **Typical Path:** `%APPDATA%\ai_translate\settings.json` (Windows)

---

### 8. **Adding New Settings - Pattern**

To add a new setting, follow this pattern:

**Rust (lib.rs):**
1. Add field to `AppSettings` struct
2. Add default value in `impl Default`
3. Update `get_settings` to read from store
4. Update `save_settings` to accept and persist the field
5. Update `save_settings` to update cache

**React (Settings.tsx):**
1. Add state variable
2. Load in `loadSettings()`
3. Add UI control
4. Pass to `save_settings` invoke call

---

### 9. **Key Design Patterns**

| Pattern | Implementation |
|---------|-----------------|
| **Caching** | In-memory `Arc<RwLock<>>` for fast access |
| **Persistence** | JSON store via `tauri_plugin_store` |
| **Validation** | Frontend + backend validation |
| **Events** | `settings-updated` event for cross-window sync |
| **Async** | All commands are async for non-blocking I/O |
| **Error Handling** | Result types with descriptive error messages |

---

This structure provides a clean, extensible settings system with proper separation between frontend UI, backend logic, and persistent storage. The caching mechanism ensures performance while the event system keeps the UI synchronized across windows.

[package]
name = "simple_translate"
version = "0.1.0"
description = "Simple Translate - Windows Desktop Translation Tool"
authors = ["you"]
edition = "2021"

# See more keys and their definitions at https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/manifest.html

[lib]
# The `_lib` suffix may seem redundant but it is necessary
# to make the lib name unique and wouldn't conflict with the bin name.
# This seems to be only an issue on Windows, see https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/issues/8519
name = "simple_translate_lib"
crate-type = ["staticlib", "cdylib", "rlib"]

[build-dependencies]
tauri-build = { version = "2", features = [] }

[dependencies]
tauri = { version = "2", features = ["tray-icon"] }
tauri-plugin-opener = "2"
tauri-plugin-single-instance = "2"
serde = { version = "1", features = ["derive"] }
serde_json = "1"
tauri-plugin-global-shortcut = "2.3.1"
tauri-plugin-clipboard-manager = "2.3.2"
reqwest = { version = "0.13.1", features = ["json"] }
enigo = "0.6.1"
arboard = "3.6.1"
log = "0.4.29"
env_logger = "0.11.8"
rdev = "0.5.3"
tauri-plugin-store = "2"
once_cell = "1.19"
tokio = { version = "1", features = ["sync"] }

[target.'cfg(windows)'.dependencies]
window-vibrancy = "0.5"

```rust
#[tauri::command]
async fn update_autostart(app: &AppHandle, enable: bool) -> Result<(), String> {
    let autostart_manager = app.autolaunch();

    if enable {
        autostart_manager.enable()
            .map_err(|e| format!("Failed to enable autostart: {}", e))?;
        info!("Autostart enabled");
    } else {
        autostart_manager.disable()
            .map_err(|e| format!("Failed to disable autostart: {}", e))?;
        info!("Autostart disabled");
    }

    Ok(())
}
```
